subject: Home & DIY
title: Roman Public Toilets Were Social Spaces
description: A 60-second lesson on Roman Public Toilets Were Social Spaces.

hook.text: Roman public toilets had no stalls. Citizens sat side by side on stone benches with keyhole openings, chatting away.

buildup.text: Running water below the seats flushed waste into the sewer. A shallow channel in front carried water for washing.

discovery.text: Instead of paper, Romans used a sponge on a stick (tersorium) dipped in vinegar. This communal tool was shared.

twist.text: The toilets were risky: methane from sewers below could ignite. Some Romans prayed to Fortuna before sitting down.

climax.text: Public toilets were where deals, gossip, and political talk happenedâ€”the original networking venue.

punchline.text: Romans networked where we'd rather be alone.

quiz.question: What unexpected danger did Roman public toilets pose?
options: Methane buildup from sewers could ignite
The stone seats could crack and collapse into the sewer
Rats from the sewers frequently emerged through the openings
